Let me recall that in E. coli, when dealing with recombination frequencies between replication origins, the number of recombinant colonies is approximately (1 - rf)/2. So if we have X recombinant colonies on strain K and Y on B, assuming X and Y are roughly equal due to random segregation, then rf = 1 - 2*(min(X,Y)/N), where N is the total number of colonies. Here, N = X + Y. So if X=4 and Y=40, min is 4, N=44. So rf = 1 - 2*(4/44) = 1 - 8/44 = 1 - 2/11 ≈ 0.818, which is ~82%. But that's way too high, and none of the options match. C. 1.5 percent

D. 0.1 percent

E. 0.2 percent

F. 0.3 percent

G. 0.5 percent

H. 5 percent

I. 0.02 percent

J. 0.05 percent

A plate of E. coli strain B is infected by two types of mutantphage simultaneously. The resultinglysateis divided inhalf. Half is diluted 1:10^7 and plated onto a lawn of E. coli strainB. The other half is diluted 1:10^5 and plated on strain K. Four plaques are found on K and 40 are found on B. A. 1 percent

B. 2 percent

C. 1.5 percent

D. 0.1 percent

E. 0.2 percent

F. 0.3 percent

G. 0.5 percent

H. 5 percent

I. 0.02 percent

J. 0.05 percent

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
